Case for 32x32mm FPV cameras. The camera I used is this one: http://bit.ly/1OJXdaC
Main features:

  • Full protection of all the parts, including lens.
  • Tilt angle for racing.
  • Hole for M3 screw so you can custom a more aggressive angle.
  • Holes for zip ties.
  • 4 screw holes.
  • Material friendly. No support / No rafts.
    Any tips are quite welcome! They will help me going on with free designs. Thanks!
    Please, like and subscribe to my youtube channel: https://www.youtube.com/user/gransmith

Notes:

You can use 1mm perimeters and about 10% to reduce the weight. If your printer can handle, reduce as much as possible the amount of material, so you save same weight.
Lens face should face the heatbed when positioning for printing.

description.text:
UPDATE
The Frag Grenade pieces were threaded incorrectly so I uploaded another version of the Top to hopefully fix it. If you already have these files download, mirror either one in Cura or whatever software you use or redownload the Frag Top.

Props of grenades found in Fallout 4.

  • Fragmentation Grenade
  • Cryogenic Grenade
  • Plasma Grenade
  • Nuka Grenade
  • Pulse Grenade

Instructions for printing and assembly.
Fragmentation Grenade
The simplest print out. Main body and the sping loaded segment screw together.

Cryogenic Grenade
Print:
1 of the main body
2 of the connection rods
2 of the end segments

Screw the connection rods into the main body and then tighten the ends on the rods.

Plasma Grenade
Print off 1 of each
Top
Connection rod
Bottom

Screwn the rod into the bottom and then tighten the top.

Nuka Grenade
Print:
1 Top
1 Middle
1 Bottom
2 Connection Rod

Screw 1 rod into the bottom, tighten the middle onto the bottom. Screw the second rod into the top of the Middle and then tighten the Top onto the rod.

Updated

Pulse Grenade
Print:
1 Top
1 Bottom
1 Connecting Rod

comments.text: Is it just me or are the threads of the frag grenade bottom incorrect for the top (or the top incorrect for the bottom?  They don't screw together because when put together the threads are going the same direction instead of opposing.  The Bottom threads are clockwise tighten but the threads in the top are counter-clockwise tighten.
comments.author: Scifideity

comments.text: I went back and checked the models and you are correct. I am so sorry for this error. I will post an updated model later and go over the other models in this collection. In the mean time, a quick fix would be to mirror either half of the grenade and that should spin the threads in the opposite direction. Again, I am very sorry and my deepest appreciation for bringing this to my attention.
comments.author: Scifideity

comments.text: Thanks dood!  I've got the printer going right now on the new top.  :)
comments.author: BlueFenix

comments.text: No problem, I'd love to know how it turns out and to see your sons cosplay when it's ready.
comments.author: Scifideity

comments.text: No worries man.  I was just wanting to bring it up and make sure I wasn't just doing something wrong.  If you reverse the threads in the top part then it'll save me a reprint of the bottom which was the longer of the two prints.  It's a great model and will go very well with my son's Fallout Cosplay for Dragon*Con next month :)

description.text:
I wanted a replacement stand for the Wanhao Duplicator i3 that would allow the spool to rotate smoothly so the extruder would not jerk the spool. I also wanted it to mount using the two existing screw locations and accomodate any size spool.

This is my second try at a the spool stand, the first version had a problem with the top of the inside supports hitting the filament when the spool was full. This new version hopefully fixes that problem. I also changed the design so that it now prints in three parts; a base and two sliders. The base mounts in the stock location on top of the printer and the two sliders slide onto the base. The spool rolls on four u-shaped bearings (guide wire bearings). The sliders have a hole for a m4 screw to lock the slider in position on the base, locking down one slider is sufficient since the deep u-shape of the bearings will keep the other slider in place. The only difference between the two sliders is the location of this hole.

The bearings are U624ZZ4 bearings (4x13x7mm) that you can get several places on-line. I got mine from Amazon here
The bearings are held in place by 4x20mm cap screws and nuts.

Update: I added a slider file that is a filament guide that goes between the two supports. The guide has a threaded hole in the back for a 3mm screw that should keep the guide in place, can't say how well the screw will work, I've been using a large binder clip. The guide doesn't include the filament filter, I'm using the one available here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:492067

If you print this stand please let me know if you have any problems or suggestions and post a picture. Thanks.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Printed in PLA with supports only to build platform.

description.text:
This is a Raspberry Pi Cluster case, which I've dubbed "MultiPi"
(Get it? Multiply? Hardee, har, har!)

  1. Print the Upper and Lower, and put a RasPi in it!
  2. Print the base for stability!
  3. Print the Middle anytime you need to add another Pi!

This is still a thing in progress... Files may change!!

P.S. While you can technically stack 10, 20, or even 100 Raspberry
Pi's using this case, it's not really recommended due to instability issues.
You've been warned!

EDIT (5/27):
I've updated all .stl files. Here are the changes:

  1. Flattened the top of the Upper and the bottom of the lower, mostly to make printing easier (reduced chances of warping).
  2. Redesigned all three pieces with the objective of making the Middle a little easier to print.
  3. Widened the case a bit, to allow more airflow, and to allow easier removal of a RPi.
  4. Added a different middle piece, which has no holes for video/audio, since most clusters' slave nodes aren't used for such.
  5. Adjusted the size of the power, HDMI, and audio holes.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.200

30%

Notes:

Supports are helpful when printing the middle and necessary when printing the base, but the upper and lower should print fine without.

description.text:
While this isn't a particularly new approach to building 3D filament spool holders, this design is simple to make and is 100% printable, except for the 22x8mm or 16x8mm ball bearings. These bearings are very common and readily available on eBay for 35-80 cents each, depending on the particular seller and quantity.

The Single-Width versions require the larger (22mm OD x 8mm bore x 7mm wide) bearings, while the One-Size-Fits-All design uses the smaller (16mm OD x 8mm bore x 5mm wide) bearings.

The saddle dimensions are the center-to-center distances between the spool flanges of many popular filament brands: 50mm matches XYXprinting refill spools (as well as those liberated from Da Vinci cartridges); 75mm fits WYZworks and similar 1Kg spools; and the intermediate (62.5mm) width fits Excelvan and similar spools. There are other spool widths out there, but these are the three that I've found to be readily available at reasonable cost.

The One-Size-Fits-All saddle, of course will accept all of the above, as well as any others that are less than about 80mm across.

Printer:

XYZ Da Vinci AiO 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Good

Infill:

Default

Notes:

The rectangular filament guide openings include built-in 0.5mm "supports" which are easily removed following printing.

The printed pivot pins are designed to be a snug press fit into the mating holes in the saddle frames as well as the bearing bores. I've found it a good idea to clean out the printed holes with an 8mm (letter size "O") drill bit, and then remove any rough spots on the pins with a small file or a bit of sandpaper. If the pins can be pushed into the bearings without undue difficulty, they should also fit the frames satisfactorily.
These designs are admittedly similar to some I've seen around the Web, but I can't recall any like the One-Size-Fits-All design. All were done using 123D Design software.

title: FPV mount for CC1333-B Board Camera - ZMR 250

description.text:
I used this to mount a CC1333 Board Camera in my ZMR-250

The reason for the raised points on the back of the mount was to give space for the crystal component on the circuit board to be held clear of the mount.

The lugs top and bottom slot into the top and bottom base plate holes, they were slightly loose though so i put a little foam tape on the front of the mount which presses against the base plate spacers and thus stops the camera vibrating.

I have uploaded a second file (V3) with the face thickened by 0.5mm

I had mine printed in ABS and superglued the camera board to the mount.

This is an adjustable Z endstop for the Eclips3d printer, but can be used by any printer to adjust an end stop.

After using the previous adjuster, I notice it was difficult to adjust easily because of it's placement on the z platform. So I went and redesigned the adjuster to fit on the frame instead of the platform.

I recommend manually moving the bed in place to touch the hot-end, with whatever surface you've installed on the bed. Then lower the adjuster to trigger the endstop. Tighten the screw to lock it into place.

This is my new tensioning finger of Inmoov . Very easy installation (10 minutes) including elastics . ( need to remove spring system )
if need repair one day stem retires in 30s and is recovering so fast.
for the rod I use a PLA ( 8cm lenght ) , of course you can use other material for rod :)
for elastic i use children's elastic ( they make bracelets with that XD )
1-print this part
2-remove support
3-slide this part under servo support
4-screw this part
5-install all elastics on tendon
6-slide the rod inside all elastics
7-place the rod on tensioner

title: Customizable Segmented Ball and Socket Joint

description.text:
Use this as the basis for building your own poseable structures.

Basic options are:
Rows/Columns - How many units to print.
Ball Radius - Radius of the ball in the segment (mm).
Neck Length - Distance between the ball and the socket (mm).
Fluid Radius - Radius of the hollowed out section through the segment.
Relief Slots - Number of slots in the socket - more slots = easier snapping together/apart. Can be removed altogether by setting to zero.

Advanced options are:
Socket Tolerance - determine how tight a fit your segments are.
Socket Ring Pct - Percentage of the lower hemisphere of the socket to print, to make snapping parts together easier or harder. Careful: Too large a value and the parts will not snap together!
Separation - Space in mm between printed segments.
Slot Width - Width in mm of each of the relief slots in the socket.

description.text:
This is an expansion to the current coffee bean bin 'Cuisinart DGB-700HA Hopper Assembly' on DGB-900BC Cuisinart coffee maker, the one that holds the beans, grinds the beans and pours in the water.

It allows adding a full lb of coffee beans to be stored in the coffee maker instead of under 1/2 lb. It raises the height of the coffeemaker but still fits under common cabinet heights in the USA.

The existing lid is removed, this bin is pushed into the other coffee bean bin, and the lid is placed on this bin. The rubber seal is left where it is on the old bin. That seal will keep the expansion bin in place. If the bin doesn't exactly fit in the front (hint hint. it won't), then grind it down or heat the front bottom in a bowl of very very hot water. Then shove it into the old coffeemaker bin.

I traced the existing bin on paper, scanned to a jpg, imported to cura, exported as stl, imported to Meshmixer, extruded and copied. Meshmixer would leave gaps between the rings. This was my first design. I had a lot of fun.

I also added an automatic water filler but I'll publish that slightly later... (I can't remember where I got all the original parts from.)

comments.text: You rock. I was just working up the design for this and I thought "lets see if someone has already done it". Thank you.
comments.author: naviathan

comments.text: I left out some details... I printed it, dunked it in boiling water and pressed it in and put the lid on.

Made a mistake in eagle had to make a quick fix. Fastest and cheapest solution a part that makes it possible to bend an DIP28 ic socket with long legs to an DIL28. Disclaimer not the prettiest solution! I will check my work twice next time!

comments.text:
Great idea though!
Usually dip chips like Atmega328P-PU come with pins a little apart and in order to plug the chip to the narrow socket one needs to bend these pins inwards. Surely the design for that purpose should be a little different than in your case, but the inventors credit is unequivocally yours!
Thanks! Great idea!
comments.author: glassy

description.text:
This design is a first test for material stability, functionality and connections.
The first print is still running, so expect files to change.

Use a good amount of infill for the bow, the trigger and the base parts.
Rotate the parts as required for your printer. There are no critical overhangs but a few very easy bridges if aligned correctly.
After printing, the base parts must be glued together with the base connector.

All holes are designed to use 2.85mm filament to connect the parts.

Update 1:
Updated ClipOnGuide to be placed more easy
Added Mount for 6mm Laser Diode

Update 2:
LaserCase modified to fit the ceap 3V 6mm laser diodes (PCB not centered)
BaseCon with new chamfer to remove sharp edge
BaseFront and BaseBack update for more stability at connection point

Please be aware: This is not a real weapon! If you are lucky, you are able to "fire" a small pencil before the bow breaks :-)

Update 3:
It works as designed: With a few household rubberbands it is able to shoot a small pen about 4m :-)

description.text: I got tired of my GoPro looking at the ground every time I checked while I was out riding. There is nothing more frustrating them losing tons of footage of you or your friends doing something cool, only to find out you didn't get because the camera mount swivels wouldn't stay tight. Well I solved it.....hehehehe

Printer Brand:

Solidoodle

Printer:

Solidoodle 3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print as it is, you may have to sand slightly due to printer differences but it works. I've dropped my helmet, taken a dive off the bike and have yet to have an issue with 20% infill. Enjoy
This is a display panel for a 2.42", 128x64 OLED screen. Featuring 5 12mm buttons and 1 10k potmeter. Ment to be fittet onto a surface.

This was a class project from the NCC Fab Lab.

In this class we took a group of students and put them through their paces. The objective of the course was to teach them some basic CAD, 3D printing, laser cutting , vinyl plotting etc.

Leonardo is a "+" style 450 quadcopter. We used a "+" configuration to make it easier for first time builders/ fliers to visualize how the flight system worked in relation to the air frame. As built Leonardo has the power and stability to do a fair amount of lifting.

There are tons of ways this design could be improved and we encourage everyone to do so on their own. Our course was not a class to build the best and most awesome quadcopter out there, but rather more about using various processes to create something.

I'm posting the files up here so that students can get access to the files they may need for replacement parts and to give them a place to flaunt their efforts ,design changes, successes and failures...

Printer Brand:

Stratasys

Printer:

uPrint SE

Supports:

Yes

As I have more time I'll post more info about the process...

For now take a look at the BOM it has a list of all the parts that were purchased to build the quadcopters in class.

The air frame is made from Baltic Birch plywood. It has been designed as a modular unit, where as the arms can be replaced individually,if they become damaged in a crash. However, this modular design allows the airframe to have a bit of flex.

Glueing the arms to the hubs using some Titebond III wood glue will help make the airframe much more ridged. If you choose to do this, keep in mind in the event of a crash the entire airframe may need to be replaced. The design could also be substantially minimalized by using a more rigid material, such as carbon fiber or G10.

The landing gear were 3D printed on a U-Print using standard support material and ABS for the model material. I suppose you could use PLA without any issue if need be. There are 2 different files for the landing gear, one is longer than the other. Other than that there are no real differences. I prefer the longer ones for basic flight, it helps keep the props out of taller grass at the flying field. These could be made much longer to facilitate a belly camera or other attachment if needed.

The flight control is an Open Pilot CC3D set up using Open Pilot's ground control software.

title: Rowlet - Pokemon Sun & Moon Grass Starter

description.text:
For more information please watch this video: https://youtu.be/tT5e7fUJAcs

It's time for another 3D model for you guys! This time I chose to make Rowlet, the new Grass Starter from Pokémon Sun & Moon. I also plan on making the other two starters very soon so make sure you get subscribed!

I created this model in Fusion 360 using their sculpting/forms tools. I created the main body using a box form. I just pulled out different spots until I had the shape I wanted. Then I created a sketch for the eyes and various details throughout the body. I extruded those and cut the form into pieces in order to keep the curvature on those details. The feet were created from sketches.

Print Settings: (Robo 3D R1)
Layer Height: 0.1mm
Infill: 20%
Supports: Yes
Raft: Yes
Print Time: ~7 hours

Post Processing:
Step 1: Sand/File any rough spots.
Step 2: Apply plastic primer. Give it a few coats, letting it dry completely in between.
Step 3: Apply a slightly off-white acrylic paint to his eyes and lower body. We used a sponge for fast and easy coverage.
Step 4: Apply a tan color to the outer feathers using the same technique as Step 3.
Step 5: Then we used a paintbrush to apply color to the details like the green feather/tail, and his feet and eyes.
Step 6: Let dry and enjoy!

description.text: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-wIqyoYKauI&feature=share&list=UUCeyR7I7HaKJI3WO5NuDoog Slixtar is a 3D printed MIDI controller. You can customize and configure it anyway you want. You 3D Print the case, get the compontents and assemble everything yourself. You can porgram the Makey Makey and Flora to do anything you want! Slixtar is a change from the typical midi boxes with square buttons on a grid. The form factor allows you to stand up and shred like a musician. Break away from the square buttons and keys and jam out. The configuration is customizable so you can make it just for you. Great for live performances, sequencing and producing. Slixtar Website

Parts List:
1 MakeyMakey
1 Adafruit Flora
4 Neo-Pixels
1 Audio Mic
4 Arcade Buttons
6 LED Push Buttons
1 Lithium Battery
1 Tactile On/Off Switch The MakeyMakey can be used to configure up to 12 buttons. LED push buttons can be powered by V5, D14 and D16 pinsrespectively. Using the Arduino IDE, you can remap pins A0-A5 to be used as additional keys. Using a virtual midi app like vmpk, you can map MIDI CCs and notes to the MakeyMakey. You can use Garageband or Ableton Live to play back samples, play virtual synths and even DJ. You can configure the buttons to do whatever your imagination can come up with. Make it yours! The FLORA can be used to power 4 Neo-pixel LEDs that can animate to the sound it detects from the audio mic, acting as a level meter! Using the open source code from Adafruit, you can easily configure the FLORA. The Neo-pixel LEDs are also completely configurable! PLA
20% Infill
2 Shells
240c Extruders
80/100 mm/s Speed
The total print time is about 10 hours but your results may vary. The body frame and neck frame will be held together by 4 3/8 pan phillips screws. The body and neck front covers snap tightly into the frame. Each LED button will require 4 wires. The Arcade buttons only require 2 wires each. All of the wires require soldering into the contacts of each button. Once the frames and from covers are assembled and all of the buttons are mounted, measure the length of the wires required for each button. The MakeyMakey micro-controller snuggly fits into the top left of the body. Pins D0-D5 and A0-A5 will be used for wiring up each button. To wire the LED buttons, use D14, D16 and 5V respectively. Label each wire before soldering any connections. Test out the MakeyMakey connections with alligator clips or wrapping wires to all the contacts. Audio Mic & Neo Pixels The Flora micro-controller will power 4 neo-pixels and 1 audio mic. Daisy chain the neo-pixels using wire. Measure and wire up the neo-pixels to D6, GRND and VBATT pins. Use pins 3.3v, GRND and D9 to wire up the micro to the flora. Use a hot glue gun to keep the neo-pixels and audio mic from dislodging while playing. The tactile on/off switch will need to be connected to the lithium battery. The tactile switch clips onto the bottom of the neck back cover and connects to the flora. Mapping MIDI Connect the MakeyMakey to your computer with USB. Download Ardiuno IDE and the MakeyMakey scratch code to modify the key settings. Use Ardiuno IDE to edit the settings file to your desired keyboard characters. You can use a virtual midi app like VMPK to map keyboard characters into MIDI notes or CCs.

title: htc vive lighthouse suspended ceiling hooks

description.text:
Use these hooks to connect the HTC Vive lighthouse vertically on your suspended ceiling, without ruining your ceiling.
(The lighthouses must be placed vertically and not pointing down too much, so simply tie-wrapping the original bracket to the ceiling won't work well)

06-06-2016: updated the model to be 4mm thick. This must minimize flexing of the material.
18-07-2016: removed the interior faces that can get some software to cough up nastyness.

construction

  1. Add a pair of m4 bolts and nuts to connect the lighthouse bracket to the hook and clamp, but don't tighten it yet.
    (If you ran out of bolts or nuts you can always jab a tie-wrap through the holes to secure the lighthouses. )

  2. Clamp the hook over the suspended ceiling and tighten the nut.

  3. Connect everything

  4. Recallibrate

  5. Play!

title: Afinia Belt Block Front to Back (y-axis) Anchor

description.text:
This is a more robust version of the belt block that comes (3D printed) with the Afinia 479 and 480 printers.

If you have slop in your build plate front to back after the machine has been initialized, you likely have a cracked belt block inside the arm that holds the build plate. If it no longer prints due to layers not lining up and need to print this, use acetone to weld it back together. I got a week out of my original belt block after using acetone to fix it but it did break again so I redesigned and printed the one I'm uploading here to make the printer reliable again.

  1. remove build plate (don't lose the three springs under the build plate)
  2. use a 2.5mm allen wrench to remove four visible allen head screws on the arm holding the build plate
  3. lift top portion of arm off, note the position of the tensioner spring on the left of the belt and belt block on the right of the spring (reassemble these in the same position relative each other)
  4. remove two 2.5mm allen head screws from the top of the belt block
  5. carefully extricate the flex circuit from the belt block
  6. put new belt block in place
  7. reassemble

I had some left over 40mm 12v festoon bulbs, so made these fixtures to mount them in the corners of my Bot.

Bulbs are from: http://www.superbrightleds.com/cgi-bin/store/index.cgi?action=DispPage&Page2Disp=%2Ffestoon.html Print the parts. I these are set up to only fit on one side. I have one in each corner, so use the mirror function in RepG to print a left and right. Run a couple of wires from a 12v line on one of the spare molex connectors on your bot. Route these up to the fixture, through the center hole, then route one to each side, pressed into the printed groove. fan out a little of the lead. The bulb will touch these wires and light up when you power your bot up. They can be placed where ever you need them, or removed for a little close up action. They can also be tilted down. This is the last of many derivatives to get something that I liked. The predecessors are in the Sketchup file.

description.text: customized with 3D Slash!

This is simple remix of the string tensioner posted by stewarma.  
Replace the screws in the printer bed with these and some nuts and you can adjust your X axis string tension by tightening the screw.  
STL includes two parts, which are mirrors of each other; one for each end of the print bed.

This version extends the part the bolt fits through to the whole thickness of the base, so that you can use a nut on the end to hold the screw tight. Since this design is meant to be used with a nut, the hole exists in the model for the full depth, unlike the original. STL includes two parts, which are mirrors of each other; one for each end of the print bed. Note
=
If you don't want to lose any of your print volume in the X axis, you'll need to cut some material off of your Printrbot Simple. You'll need to cut out one or two notches, depending on if you use one or two tensioners. I've included a pic showing the notches I've made in my Simple (even though I'm only using one tensioner on the Right side of my print bed) as well as a pic of the tensioner with the printer in use. Disclaimer
=
Any modification of your Printer is taken at your own risk, with no warranty or guarantee provided by myself nor Thingiverse; either express or implied. That said, if you do, make sure you keep your bearings clean! Cover them before cutting.

Two gear sets for 50mm or 2 inch venetian blinds with square rod.

title: Scifi Storage Crate Stands
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to make an angled stand for the Scifi Storage Crate that I made so I could store the unit underneath something with ease.

I also created versions of this stand that mate with the stackable version so that you stack them. Print either the "pos" or "neg" version to suit the type of notch on the bottom of your stackable container. I wouldn't recommend stacking them to high though as only the first level would have a supported back.

The posted pictures of the model are of an earlier version of the part. I removed material around the base, which can be seen in the renderings of the parts, to cut down on material usage and about an hour of run time.

Printer:

Qidi Tech

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

15%

Clean up.

When I printed this, I enabled support because I figured there might be problems in some areas. I forgot that this often likes to put supports inside things like screw holes. Make sure the clear out the screw holes on the sides so a screw can go through there.

Joining multiple stands together.

Using a M3 nut and M3 x 20mm screw, a pair of stands can be conjoined together through the hold on the side near the bottom. Find the insert on the inside and place the nut in there, it should be a snug fit but support material likes to hide in there.

description.text:
This is a reel for 35mm film tank developing. Holds 36 exposure rolls for processing in tanks with a 1" center tube.

The model includes two ball bearings, one on either side of the reel, to add traction to the film as it is loaded into the reel. Might be problematic using different slicer/printer combos than I am. Let me know if you have any bad results!

To generate your own reel at higher or lower resolution, beware: the script takes a long time to generate the geometry of the spiral. Rewrites will focus on improving the performance of the spiral generator, but aside from render times I haven't had any issues slicing and printing the .STLs.

description.text:
Tray that holds the player model, the shield tokens, player order token, Armor tokens, ability tokens and the starting deck for a player.

This is one-size fits all for the different players. It's a bit more wasted space than I'd normally prefer, and I'd have preferred giving the shield tokens their own tray, but with such an awkward shape as a figure and such variety in sizes, there was little choice. This case will fit any of the player figures including the large ones such as Krang or Goldyx. (The size was chosen based on Goldyx, which is the largest figure. Unfortunately, the size of the stands, which are permanent on my tokens won't allow for much savings for the rest of the characters)

I thought the window in the top to display the player card was a clever addition. Makes them easy to identify at a glance. Well, assuming your friends put them back properly :)

The cases come in just over the lip of the box bottom (half a mm or so, not much) when laid on their long sides, and it should be possible to fit 5 in a row.

Model was slightly tweaked after print displayed above to add 1mm to the card posts, and 2 mm to the cover to account for a small gap between the base and the cover.

print_settings.Notes:: You can use a raft but it's a waste of filament. I recommend using a bigger nozzle if you can as it will reduce your print times drastically. You may need supports if some part of the castle is hanging over but I told my students to make sure everything was build from the ground up.

title: 3D Printed Minecraft Castle Teaches Perimeter and Area

description.text: I realized that 3D printing is great for teaching spacial reasoning skills to students but how? I though one of the major concepts that can be taught in math is perimeter and area. It's easy to create and measure with a small object and if students make the design and print it themselves it will greatly increase the chances of them learning the actual concept not just how to calculate it.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

.20

Notes:

You can use a raft but it's a waste of filament. I recommend using a bigger nozzle if you can as it will reduce your print times drastically. You may need supports if some part of the castle is hanging over but I told my students to make sure everything was build from the ground up.

Basic process and design

I had my students use minecraft to design their castles and then exported them using Mineways to print them on our 3d printers. As far as using minecraft to design it I downloaded a map from the minecraftedu library that allowed my students to teleport into their own workspace so that no one can enter but them.
For the castle I would make sure they used at least 7-10 blocks for the height of the castle walls and two blocks deep and two blocks wide for the moat. This will help when you print it out. I also made them create rooms inside the castle and taught them about birds eye view and basic blueprint design principal. I went over and the typical aspects of castles and the purpose of a moat before hand. This is where the perimeter concept ties in. I then had them research minecraft castles with moas for inspiration. The area concept ties in when you get the area of the castle. Advanced concepts would include volume of castle and exact area if their castle isn't a perfect square or rectangle. The unit of measure is any label you choose, inches feet etc, since minecraft is a block system it works very well. I found that my students were really interested in this lesson because they got to take the castle home.

Assuming this will happen in a classroom students will learn the conceptual foundation to understand perimeter and area. The learning begins with basic design principals applied in minecraft using a medieval theme. Castles had moats for a reason which is a great way to teach perimeter. Area soon follows with the inside castle area being compared to the area including the moat and a discussion as to why they are different. Once printed students can make a real connection with the difference between perimeter and area. Objectives
Understand the difference between perimeter and area. Skills Learned (Standards)
Standard 3.MD.8: Solve real world problems involving perimeters of polygons, including finding the perimeter given the side lengths and finding an unknown side length, and exhibiting rectangles with the same perimeter and different areas or with the same area and different perimeters and asks students to solve for perimeter using real-world problems. Math: 4.MD.3
Measurement And Data Sub-Category
Solve Problems Involving Measurement And Conversion Of Measurements From A Larger Unit To A Smaller Unit. State Standard
Apply the area and perimeter formulas for rectangles in real world and mathematical problems. For example, find the width of a rectangular room given the area of the flooring and the length, by viewing the area formula as a multiplication equation with an unknown factor. Grade 5 is a bit tougher but still doable. Grade 5 Module 5: Addition and Multiplication with Volume and Area In this 25-day module, students work with two- and three-dimensional figures. Volume is introduced to students through concrete exploration of cubic units and culminates with the development of the volume formula for right rectangular prisms. The second half of the module turns to extending students’ understanding of two-dimensional figures. Students combine prior knowledge of area with newly acquired knowledge of fraction multiplication to determine the area of rectangular figures with fractional side lengths. They then engage in hands-on construction of two-dimensional shapes, developing a foundation for classifying the shapes by reasoning about their attributes. This module fills a gap between Grade 4’s work with two-dimensional figures and Grade 6’s work with volume and area. Duration
It take about 5-7 1-period classes for most students to finish their castles. It can take a bit to print them out depending on how many printers you have and what nozzle diameter you use to print it. Expect to go through a few roll of PLA. I wouldn't use ABS unless you can absolutely make the print stick. Some of these castles can take 4-5 hours to print with a .4mm nozzle.

• Begin with MinecraftEdu if you can. It's about $500 for a server license and 32 workstation licenses. If you can do that then just get the regular minecraft license.

  • Next download mineways. It's free and pretty easy to use after watching a five minute youtube video.

  • Now go over the basics of castles and moats with a focus on why there was a moat to begin with. Now connect that with the concept of perimeter. Using real world concepts with academic vocabulary to introduce profound understanding.

  • Review their minecraft design and make sure the walls are tall enough and the moat is deep enough to come out when you print them.

  • Download the minecraft map using mineways and save it as an stl.

  • Print out the design and have your student label it and paint it to look like a castle.

  • Teach your students that minecraft is a block system and each block counts as one. You can choose whatever unit of measure you want but I would start with "block." Have them say my castle has a perimeter of "X" blocks. This allows them to understand the concept. Later you can have them measure other objects and introduce units of measure after they understand the concept.
5-7 class periods

Students should know about minecraft and how to use it or expect to do some lessons on using it. Youtube is great for that. If their not accustomed to using a keyboard and mouse give them time to practice.
My only assessment was that they could label their castle with the correct perimeter and area.

minecraftedu: http://education.minecraft.net/minecraftedu/ mineways: http://www.realtimerendering.com/erich/minecraft/public/mineways/ how to use it:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xmsnE85GNV8 youtube link on minecraft: https://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=minecraft+tutorial

description.text: Based on a wooden star puzzle.

The half-sized ones print up quickly (5 min per piece) but are very difficult to put together, and don\'t stay together well.

description.text: Undercabinet housing for 24v and 12v dimmer controls.

All electricals from: http://www.superbrightleds.com/cgi-bin/store/index.cgi?action=DispPage&Page2Disp=%2Fspecs%2Fdimmer.htm The 12v volt is LDP-2A, with the housing removed. The 24v is LDR-2A with the remote control knob. This unit lives on top of the cabinet, and the remote is routed into the the area behind the cover. Both controls extend into the valance, so make sure to cut out for this before installation of the cabinets.We use a fitted/ scribed valance add on that this cover is mounted to, then a hole is cut in the cabinet bottom corner for the wiring to pass through. this particular cabinet didn't have room for a wire chase so everything is routed through the inside corner and then has a decorative cover inside to make it clean and nice. Sketchup file included for your perusal.

RandomEngy made a nice rendition of the wobbler I found here, but it wasn't perfect. Primarily, there were corners on it. I wanted to make a more faithful recreation. Using the math found here (hooray for Numberphile), I made this in SolidWorks. I haven't printed it yet, but It should work, unless I missed something mathematically.

title: HTC Vive - Cable Support - Waist/Belt Clip

description.text:
Updated 1/27/17: Now includes support for the round cable shipping with newer headsets.

A simple clip that allows you attach your HTC Vive's headset cable to your waist band or belt. This makes the headset much more comfortable, since the bulk of the cable weight and movement drag is transferred from your head to your waist.

Printer:

Mankati Fullscale XT Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 or .1

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Make sure that you print in the default orientation so your that your print layers/direction give both parts maximum strength where they need it. PLA works well.

Simply slide the 'CableHolder' into the 'BeltClip' slot and your good to go.

To figure out where to attach the CableHolder part to the Vive's Headset Cable:

  1. Put on the Vive headset as you normally wear it.
  2. Bend over so you're touching the floor (this will let you know how much cable slack you need).
  3. While your bent over, note where the cable is touching your waist while hanging down the middle of your back.
  4. Slide the Vive's headset cable into your printed CableHolder part - about an inch below the area you marked in step 3. Note that a friction fit should be sufficient to hold the part in place!

With a little coaxing, the CableHolder part should slide in and out of the BeltClip part... It was designed this way so that you can attach multiple CableHolder parts to the Vive's cable (for different sized users) while sharing the same printed BeltClip.

description.text:
Needed a version of the extruder mounted to my X carriage plate, so I merged the two together in OpenSCAD and printed one.

This requires a Nema17 geared stepper motor, and is designed around hobbed gears that are around 12mm diameter. Since most useful geared Nema17s have 8mm shafts, you're looking for an 8mm ID/11.4mm OD gear.

I have successfully used it with both 5:1 geared steppers and 14:1.

Other things required:
A 608zz bearing for the idler with something to act as a central shaft, either a 8mm grubscrew or a printed part.
2x M4x50mm screws for the idler.
2x M4 nuts
either M5 or M4 screws for mounting the groovemount.
Printed Shim
Printed or machined (or wood) groovemount plate. The common E3D and jhead ones work fine. The included one is a modification of another one with holes made in it for bolting a 40mm fan to it.

I don't use springs with this.

I noticed that the hinge tends to break off as the layers are parallel to a stress point in this configuration, t1_carriage.slic3r.amf and X_Carriage_shifted.stl are two different approaches to solve the problem.

The AMF file is an export from Slic3r with a modifier mesh to print the top area at 100% infill.
X_Carriage_shifted.stl should be rotated -90deg in the X axis and printed without support.

The trimmed version should be printed in the provided orientation with support.

description.text:
Have you, dear reader, ever wondered how a clock works or maybe a shutter on a film camera? Now you can learn with this interactive learning tool designed for people like you!

NOTE: Not all clocks use this technique to function, there are other ways a clock works.

                                 How does it work?
                     Well if you look into the diagrams
                     you can see a circular shape with 
                     a pin coming out the top. This pin
                     spins around and around and when
                     it touches the hexagonal shape
                     (the trigger) it moves the clock hand,
                     creating movement.  A you might 
                     have guessed, the only on a certain
                     ratio will it move. This is what depicts
                     the second hand to the hour hand,
                     minute hand to the second, ext.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Omni 1.4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 layer height

Infill:

30%

Notes:

NOTE: The objects are really small you really want to size them up before you print

First off, I was using software called blender 2.75 and this may vary on what version of blender you are using, if you are even using blender at all.

 First, I created a circle. I extruded the circle to create a base shape and then I used booleans to cut a hole in the cylinder. Before deleting the cylinder I added a base using a cube by messing around with the simple vertices. I then took the same cylinder to use booleans again to mend it on the base. NOTE: Make sure you size down the cylinder before you mend it because when it prints the pieces won't fit and you will be left with a worthless print. To create the trigger I first added a circle and set the vertices to six. I then added a cube and sized it to fit the cube shaped holes in the trigger. I then duplicated it and each time rotated it by 60 degrees until it got all the way around and selected them all. After selecting them all I used (Ctrl + J) to join them into the same object. I used booleans another time to cut that much away from the hexagonal prism to create the almost complete trigger. I then created another pivot point like I did with the wheel when I cut a cylinder out of the wheel. I next added one more cylinder and positioned it on the wheel. I used booleans again to mend it to the wheel and I was very close to done. To let it be hand powered, I created a cube and extruded it To create the handle. I used booleans for the last time to mend it to the wheel. Then it was a matter of printing from here!

Background 
 You will learn how Intermittent mechanism works and just how simple it really is!
Objectives

Students will learn mechanics and engineering on the basic structure of Intermittent mechanism and are able to show this skill being educated.

Audience

Students from grades 4th through 7th would be the recommended age for this project.

Subjects

Mechanical engineering
Science

New Skills learned

How a clock works
Problem solving
Teamwork
How to 3d print

Procedure
  1. Students will pair into groups of two.
  2. Teacher(s) will explain will explain the importance of time in daily life.
  3. Teacher(s) will tell students to communicate with his or her partner to get a good idea of how a clock works.
  4. Teacher will pass out the models and the teacher(s) will ask the students to try to figure out how it works.
  5. Teacher will show how the model works by demonstrating it in front of the class.
Lesson Time

This project has an estimated time of 30 min. (Time may vary depending on number of students).

Preporation

Students before hand need to know, basic computer skills, team communication, and a strive for knowledge.

Students will need the following:
*One dry erase marker

  • One dry erase board

Teachers will need the following:
One 3d printer per 4 students
One dry erase marker
*One dry erase board

References

For a clean animation of how it works, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OEEmQuPmVrE
and for more information, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intermittent_mechanism.

print_settings.Notes:: Trivially easy and quick print in PLA. However, you'll want to use the most opaque PLA you can find... or you'll have to paint the PLA to make it light tight.

description.text:
Would you like to be able to capture "3D" images using your current film or digital, still or movie, camera? Anaperture is a Customizer-compatible OpenSCAD program to design special dual-aperture discs that allow single-shot, single-lens, anaglyph stereo capture using a conventional still or video camera. Images captured can be seen in 3D using the usual funny-colored glasses... in fact, you can even see the camera live view in 3D that way!

This 3D-printed design creates filter masks that can fit inside the threaded filter ring of a typical DSLR lens. The color filter material itself is cut from the colored gels in a pair of viewing glasses that you can buy for under $1.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Doesn't matter

Infill:

Some

Notes:

Trivially easy and quick print in PLA. However, you'll want to use the most opaque PLA you can find... or you'll have to paint the PLA to make it light tight.

The filter material is simply cut from a pair of the anaglyph viewing glasses and taped/glued over the two holes. Using the two-part design, fix the filters on the part with the tab and then seal them in by pressing the second part in place over them with the holes aligned. It should fit in fairly tightly, but you can use two-sided tape of glue to fix it in place.

Once you've assembled the new analglyph aperture, simply pop it inside the filter thread of your lens (turn it to make the two holes horizontal) and take photos as normal with the lens aperture always set to wide open. The images captured, and even the live view, will be a stereo anaglyph! Enjoy!

You say it didn't work for you? First, make sure you didn't let the lens stop-down the aperture; that can even give something like the red and cyan spots in the 6th image. Assuming you kept the lens aperture wide open, the real trick here is sizing. Enter the appropriate data for your lens and the OpenSCAD anaperture design program will attempt to design something reasonable, but it cannot predict lens vignetting, which is a very common and often overlooked defect among fast lenses. A too-long baseline will suffer vignetting that makes each side of the image colored -- vignetting is literally clipping one of the paths through the lens so that the sides only get one view each. If this happens, try targeting something like f/8-f/11 with a very short stereo baseline -- the example images here were shot with f/11 and a baseline of just 8mm.

This is really an OpenSCAD version of the CGI script I wrote 5 years ago to create SVG designs for anaglyph apertures. There are a variety of enhancements because the 3D-printed waterhouse stops can be fully 3D parts, while the SVG designs were 2D shapes with a simple, somewhat fragile, fold-up tab.

An anaglyph is a type of stereo image in which the left and right sides are encoded in a single image by assigning approximately non-overlapping colors to each side. Although many color assignments can be used, the most common are red/cyan and green/magenta. The samples shown here are red/cyan. To see depth, you use viewing glasses that have color filters causing each eye to see only the colors assigned to that side's view.

Normally, two separate images are captured and then processed together to form the anaglyph. Instead, we can directly capture the image as an anaglyph by using filters cut from cardboard-frame viewing glasses of the same colors used for viewing. This will wreck a pair of viewing glasses, but they cost no more than $1. Alternatively, you can use photographic or stage lighting gel filters... it's not very picky, but you want to divide the spectrum into two disjoint parts that the camera's RGB capture can keep separate, which usually means either R/GB (i.e., red/cyan) or G/RB (i.e., green/magenta).

The two colors normally would be placed in front of two separate lenses, however, it suffices to create two optical paths within a single lens. This is done by a type of dual Waterhouse Stop -- a fancy name for an opaque material with two holes in it. If the holes are sized and placed correctly, and the appropriate filter is placed over each, capturing an anaglyph image can be as simple as placing this new stop in front of the lens and pressing the shutter button. It will even work for movies.

The hole size and placement are critical, and depend on some properties of the lens. (Before you ask, no, it isn't feasible for cell phone cameras because the holes would need to be too small and too accurately placed.) The original anaperture tool accepts a few key parameters, computes the ideal stop design, and generates a Scalable Vector Graphic (SVG) image of the stop for printing. Laser or inkjet print the stop image, tape color filters over the holes, cut it out, stick it in front of your lens, and capture some anaglyphs! The new version here uses OpenSCAD to design 3D-printable anaglyph apertures that are somewhat more robust.

You'll want to look at http://www.instructables.com/id/Use-Your-Camera-To-Capture-3D-Anaglyphs/ to understand more of why this works....

title: Tank wheel for use with tracks

description.text:
This was a larger wheel that interfaces with the wide tank track. It has most of the axle as part of the model. The axle size is made to fit onto a roller blade bearing. The small hole in the tip of the axle should be drilled out to accommodate whatever drive mechanism you want. In my case, I used a Tamiya gearbox from ebay. I drilled the center out to about 3.1mm and pressed it onto the gearbox shafts. The arduino drives a H bridge shield. 5v is more than enough to power the motors and will run quite a while on 4 AA batteries. The frame of my particular tank is not printed, but can easily be cut out of wood.

The front wheels are also the same model. I simply cut off the thin part of the axle and drilled out the center of the wheel to about 5.2mm and used a bolt to hold it in place.

When assembling the gearbox, ensure that the 207:1 ratio is used, not the 58:1. It will be plenty fast enough with the larger ratio and it will have enough torque to climb over things.

I added STL files for the body and the side of the tank that I show in the picture. The side of the tank will need to be mirrored in the slicer to produce the opposite side. The bearing size is 8mm (inner) x 7mm (thick) x 22mm (outer). It is held in place by 3 3mm x 10mm screws.

comments.text: From the photo, it looks like the track is printed.  Can you give a link to what you used?  Thanks in advance, ArizonaClark
comments.author: ArizonaClark

comments.text: The tracks are one of the STL  files in thing number 1213279. That was a remix of the track done by someone else.
comments.author: ArizonaClark

description.text:
After finishing my very first quad copter and taking it out for its maiden flight I have learned that you must tighten down the prop nuts pretty good. Long story short lost two props mid flight but luckily crashed into tall grass with no problems other than not finding one prop and two prop nuts.

Not wanting to wait on new ones to arrive I just made my own and they came out great! Look good with a snug fit and I don't foresee them being able to spin off like the metal ones even if they weren't tightened down. I am totally confidant in there ability to hold on the props. One thing I would worry about is them wearing out after many remove/installs.

I also included tools to help install them. ( up-scaled http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:964313 )

Update 20 May 16 : After several flights and even a couple crashes the nuts are holding strong. One suggestion I have is to print the CW and CCW in different colors. I found out the hard way that it's a pain to tell which is which when they are the same color.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Core XY

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

15

Notes:

With it set to 3 for Top, Bottom and Shell with .4 tip infill is whatever you want as the important part has no room for any. I also printed at .2 but found .1 threaded on much smoother.

comments.text: Honestly dude thanks for this! In the country I live in, they dont sell stuff like this here. This helped me out a lot after I lost a prop nut. Thanks a lot.

print_settings.Notes:: Make sure you print the extender bracket as is - on its side vertically - for strength.

description.text:
Had to order a throat for my MK8 extruder and got the 50mm one. Since the original Geetech one is 38mm, this makes the ZStop adjustment screw a tad small to reach the ZStop switch. So I added this extender and made it adjustable in height so that the adjustment screw could reach the switch without compressing the spring too much. In fact now I have 2 springs in place and it gives me proper tension.

Because of the clearance the connection tabs of the switch have to be twisted outwards as in the picture. Not a big problem. You will need 2 more M2 screws and nuts to fit the switch on the extender.

description.text:
I make, test and populate a lot of PCBs. I make jigs to hold them from time to time. Here is one of them. Tried to sell it on eBay for like a dollar a piece and no buyers yet. Oh well, there loss. ;-) So, I figured I'd make the files available to fellow tinkers. I've tried several springs. Seems the .390in radius fits the best. In terms of force, somewhere between just holding the PCBs and breaking the fixture should due. :-) Happy building.
Bill
